text: I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: Lady Wilde once told me that when she was a young girl she was stopped
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in some Dublin street by a great crowd and turned into a shop to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: escape from it. She stayed there some time and the crowd still passed.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: She asked the shopman what it was, and he said, 'the funeral of Thomas
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Davis, a poet.' She had never heard of Davis; but because she thought
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a country that so honoured a poet must be worth something, she became
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: interested in Ireland and was soon a famous patriotic poet herself,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: being, as she once said to me half in mockery, an eagle in her youth.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: That age will be an age of romance for an hundred years to come.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he passed upon a journey into the country the verses he had published
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but that morning in a Dublin newspaper; and yet we should not regret
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than are our kind elsewhere in Europe; for now that we are unpopular

text: Not all Lord Dunsany's moods delight me, for he writes out of a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: careless abundance; and from the moment I first read him I have wished
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to have between two covers something of all the moods that do. I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: believe that I have it in this book, which I have just been reading
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: aloud to an imaginative young girl more French than English, whose
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: understanding, that of a child and of a woman, and expressed not in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: words but in her face, has doubled my own. Some of my selections,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: those that I have called 'A Miracle' and 'The Castle of Time' are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: passages from stories of some length, and I give but the first act of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Argimenes,' a play in the repertory of the Abbey Theatre, but each
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: selection can be read I think with no thoughts but of itself. If 'Idle
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: imagination could have found adventures worthy of a traveller who had

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: THE GODS OF THE MOUNTAIN

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ACT I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SCENE: The East. Outside a city wall; three beggars seated on the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ground.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO These days are bad for beggary.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN They are bad.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF (an older beggar but not grey) Some evil has befallen the rich
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ones of this city. They take no joy any longer in benevolence, but are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: become sour and miserly at heart. Alas for them! I sometimes sigh for
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them when I think of this.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Alas for them. A miserly heart must be a sore affliction.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN A sore affliction indeed, and bad for our calling.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO (reflectively) They have been thus for many months. What thing
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: has befallen them?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN Some evil thing.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF There has been a comet come near to the earth of late and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth has been parched and sultry so that the gods are drowsy and all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: those things that are divine in man, such as benevolence, drunkenness,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: extravagance and song, have faded and died and have not been
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: replenished by the gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO It has indeed been sultry.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN I have seen the comet o' nights.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF The gods are drowsy.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO If they awake not soon and make this city worthy again of our
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: order, I for one shall forsake the calling and buy a shop and sit at
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ease in the shade and barter for gain.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN You will keep a shop? (Enter Agmar and Slag. Agmar, though
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: poorly dressed, is tall, imperious, and older than Ulf. Slag follows
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: behind him.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Is this a beggar who speaks?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Yes, master, a poor beggar.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR How long has the calling of beggary existed?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Since the building of the first city, Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR And when has a beggar ever followed a trade? When has he ever
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: haggled and bartered and sat in a shop?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Why, he has never done so.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Are you he that shall be first to forsake the calling?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Times are bad for the calling here.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN They are bad.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR So you would forsake the calling.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO The city is unworthy of our calling. The gods are drowsy, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all that is divine in man is dead. (To third Beggar) Are not the gods
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drowsy?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF They are drowsy in their mountains away at Marma. The seven green
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: idols are drowsy. Who is this that rebukes us?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN Are you some great merchant, Master? Perhaps you will help a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: poor man that is starving.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG My Master a Merchant! No, no. He is no merchant. My Master is no
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: merchant.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO I perceive that he is some lord in disguise. The gods have woken
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and have sent him to save us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG No, no. You do not know my Master. You do not know him.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN Is he the Soldan's self that has come to rebuke us?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (with great pride) I am a beggar, and an old beggar.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG There is none like my Master. No traveller has met with cunning
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like to his, not even those that come from Aethiopia.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF We make you welcome to our town, upon which an evil has fallen,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the days being bad for beggary.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Let none that has known the mystery of roads, or has felt the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind arising new in the morning, or who has called forth out of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: souls of men divine benevolence, ever speak any more of any trade or
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the miserable gains of shops and the trading men.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO I but spoke hastily, the times being bad.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR I will put right the times.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG There is nothing that my Master cannot do.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (to Slag) Be silent and attend to me. I do not know this city, I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have travelled from far, having somewhat exhausted the city of Ackara.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG My Master was three times knocked down and injured by carriages
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there, once he was killed and seven times beaten and robbed, and every
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: time he was generously compensated. He had nine diseases, many of them
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mortal....
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Be silent, Slag.... Have you any thieves among the calling here?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF We have a few that we call thieves here, Master, but they would
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: scarcely seem thieves to you. They are not good thieves.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR I shall need the best thief you have.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (Enter two citizens richly clad, Illanaun and Oorander)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Therefore we will send galleons to Ardaspes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Right to Ardaspes through the silver gates.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (Agmar transfers the thick handle of his long staff to his left
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armpit, he droops on to it and it supports his weight, he is upright
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: no longer. His right arm hangs limp and useless. He hobbles up to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: citizens imploring alms.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN I am sorry. I cannot help you. There have been too many
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beggars here, and we must decline alms for the good of the town.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (sitting down and weeping) I have come from far. (Illanaun
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: presently returns and gives Agmar a coin. Exit Illanaun. Agmar, erect
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, walks back to the others.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR We shall need fine raiment, let the thief start at once. Let it
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rather be green raiment.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: BEGGAR I will go and fetch the thief. (Exit)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF We will dress ourselves as lords and impose upon the city.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Yes, yes; we will say we are ambassadors from a far land.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF And there will be good eating.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG (in an undertone to Ulf) But you do not know my Master. Now that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you have suggested that we shall go as lords, he will make a better
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suggestion. He will suggest that we should go as kings.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF (incredulous) Beggars as kings!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Ay. You do not know my Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF (to Agmar) What do you bid us do?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR You shall first come by the fine raiment in the manner I have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mentioned.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF And what then, Master?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Why then we shall go as gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: BEGGARS As gods?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR As gods. Know you the land through which I have lately come in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my wanderings? Marma, where the gods are carved from green stone in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mountains. They sit all seven of them against the hills. They sit
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there motionless and travellers worship them.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF Yes, yes, we know those gods. They are much reverenced here; but
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they are drowsy and send us nothing beautiful.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR They are of green jade. They sit cross-legged with their right
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: elbows resting on their left hands, the right forefinger pointing
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upwards. We will come into the city disguised, from the direction of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Marma, and will claim to be these gods. We must be seven as they are.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And when we sit, we must sit cross-legged as they do, with the right
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand uplifted.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF This is a bad city in which to fall into the hands of oppressors,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the judges lack amiability here as the merchants lack benevolence
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever since the gods forgot them.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR In our ancient calling a man may sit at one street corner for
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fifty years doing the one thing, and yet a day may come when it is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well for him to rise up and to do another thing, while the timorous
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man starves.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF Also it were well not to anger the gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Is not all life a beggary to the gods? Do they not see all men
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: always begging of them and asking alms with incense, and bells, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: subtle devices?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Yes, all men indeed are beggars before the gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Does not the mighty Soldan often sit by the agate altar in his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: royal temple as we sit at a street corner or by a palace gate?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF It is even so.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Then will the gods be glad when we follow the holy calling with
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: new devices and with subtlety, as they are glad when the priests sing
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a new song.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF Yet I have a fear.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (to Slag) Go you into the city before us, and let there be a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophecy there which saith that the gods who are carven from green
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rock in the mountain shall one day arise in Marma and come here in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: guise of men.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Yes, Master. Shall I make the prophecy myself? Or shall it be
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found in some old document?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Let someone have seen it once in some rare document. Let it be
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spoken of in the market-place.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG It shall be spoken of, Master. (Slag lingers. Enter thief and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thahn)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO This is our thief.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (encouragingly) Ah, he is a quick thief.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF I could only procure you three green raiments, Master. The city
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is not now well supplied with them; moreover it is a very suspicious
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city, and without shame for the baseness of its suspicions.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG (to a beggar) This is not thieving.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF I could do no more, Master. I have not practised thieving all my
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: life.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR You have got something: it may serve our purpose. How long have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you been thieving?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF I stole first when I was ten.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG When he was ten!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR We must tear them up and divide them amongst the seven. (to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thahn) Bring me another beggar.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG When my Master was ten he had already had to slip by night out of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: two cities.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO (admiringly) Out of two cities!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG (nodding his head) In his native city they do not now know what
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: became of the golden cup that stood in the Lunar Temple.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Yes, into seven pieces.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF We will each wear a piece of it over our rags.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Yes, yes, we shall look fine.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR That is not the way that we shall disguise ourselves.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Not cover our rags?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR No, no. The first who looked closely would say 'These are only
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beggars. They have disguised themselves.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF What shall we do?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Each of the seven shall wear a piece of the green raiment
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: underneath his rags. And peradventure here and there a little shall
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: show through; and men shall say 'These seven have disguised themselves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as beggars. But we know not what they be.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Hear my wise Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO (in admiration) _He_ is a beggar.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF He is an _old_ beggar.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ACT II
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SCENE: The Metropolitan Hall of the city of Kongros. Citizens, etc.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Enter the seven beggars with green silk under their rags.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Who are you and whence come you?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Who may say what we are or whence we come?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER What are these beggars and why do they come here?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Who said to you that we were beggars?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Why do these men come here?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Who said to you that we were men?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Now, by the moon!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR My sister.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN What?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR My little sister.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Our little sister the Moon. She comes to us at evenings away in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mountain of Marma. She trips over the mountains when she is young:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when she is young and slender she comes and dances before us: and when
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: she is old and unshapely she hobbles away from the hills.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Yet she is young again and forever nimble with youth: yet she
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comes dancing back. The years are not able to curb her nor to bring
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grey hairs to her brethren.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER This is not wonted.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN It is not in accordance with custom.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS Prophecy hath not thought it.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG She comes to us new and nimble remembering olden loves.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER It were well that prophets should come and speak to us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN This hath not been in the past. Let prophets come; let
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophets speak to us of future things. (The beggars seat themselves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon the floor in the attitude of the seven gods of Marma.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: CITIZEN I heard men speak to-day in the market-place. They speak of a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophecy read somewhere of old. It says the seven gods shall come from
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Marma in the guise of men.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Is this a true prophecy?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER It is all the prophecy we have. Man without prophecy is like
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a sailor going by night over uncharted seas. He knows not where are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the rocks nor where the havens. To the man on watch all things ahead
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are black and the stars guide him not, for he knows not what they are.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Should we not investigate this prophecy?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Let us accept it. It is as the small uncertain light of a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lantern, carried it may be by a drunkard but along the shore of some
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: haven. Let us be guided.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS It may be that they are but benevolent gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR There is no benevolence greater than our benevolence.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN _Then_ we need do little: they portend no danger to us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR There is no anger greater than our anger.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Let us make sacrifice to them, if they be gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS We humbly worship you, if ye be gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN (kneeling too) You are mightier than all men and hold high
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rank among other gods and are lords of this our city, and have the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thunder as your plaything and the whirlwind and the eclipse and all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the destinies of human tribes, if ye be gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Let the pestilence not fall at once upon this city, as it had
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: indeed designed to; let not the earthquake swallow it all immediately
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up amid the howls of the thunder; let not infuriate armies overwhelm
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: those that escape if we be gods.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: POPULACE (in horror) If we be gods!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Come let us sacrifice.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Bring lambs.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS Quick, quick. (Exit some.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG (with solemn air) This god is a very divine god.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN He is no common god.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: MLAN Indeed he has made us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: CITIZEN (A WOMAN) (to Slag) He will not punish us, Master? None of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods will punish us? We will make a sacrifice, a good sacrifice.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ANOTHER We will sacrifice a lamb that the priests have blessed.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: FIRST CITIZEN Master, you are not wroth with us?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Who may say what cloudy dooms are rolling up in the mind of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eldest of the gods. He is no common god like us. Once a shepherd went
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by him in the mountains and doubted as he went. He sent a doom after
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that shepherd.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: CITIZEN Master, we have not doubted.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG _And the doom found him on the hills at evening._
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SECOND CITIZEN It shall be a good sacrifice, Master. (Re-enter with a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dead lamb and fruits. They offer the lamb on an altar where there is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fire, and fruits before the altar.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN (stretching out a hand to a lamb upon an altar.) That leg is not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: being cooked at all.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN It is strange that gods should be thus anxious about the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cooking of a leg of lamb.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER It is strange certainly.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Almost I had said that it was a man spoke then.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER (Stroking his beard and regarding the second beggar.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Strange. Strange certainly.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Is it then strange that the gods love roasted flesh? For this
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purpose they keep the lightning. When the lightning flickers about the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: limbs of men there comes to the gods in Marma a pleasant smell, even
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a smell of roasting. Sometimes the gods, being pacific, are pleased to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have roasted instead the flesh of lamb. It is all one to the gods: let
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the roasting stop.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER No, no, gods of the mountain!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OTHERS No, no.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER Quick, let us offer the flesh to them. If they eat all is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well. (They offer it, the beggars eat, all but Agmar who watches.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN One who was ignorant, one who did not know, had almost said
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that they ate like hungry men.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OTHERS Hush.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS Yet they look as though they had not had a meal like this for a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long time.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER They _have_ a hungry look.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (who has not eaten) I have not eaten since the world was very
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: new and the flesh of men was tenderer than now. These younger gods
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have learned the habit of eating from the lions.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER O oldest of divinities, partake, partake.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR It is not fitting that such as I should eat. None eat but beasts
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and men and the younger gods. The Sun and the Moon and the nimble
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lightning and I, we may kill, and we may madden, but we do not eat.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS If he but eat of our offering he cannot overwhelm us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ALL O ancient deity, partake, partake.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Enough. Let it be enough that these have condescended to this
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bestial and human habit.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN (to Akmos) And yet he is not unlike a beggar whom I saw not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: so long since.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OORANDER But beggars eat.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Now I never knew a beggar yet who would refuse a bowl of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Woldery wine.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS This is no beggar.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN Nevertheless let us offer him a bowl of Woldery wine.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS You do wrong to doubt him.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ILLANAUN I do but wish to prove his divinity. I will fetch the Woldery
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wine. (Exit)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS He will not drink. Yet if he does, then he will not overwhelm
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: us. Let us offer him the wine.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: FIRST BEGGAR It is Woldery wine!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: FOURTH BEGGAR O blessed day!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR It is a fitting libation. Our anger is somewhat appeased.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AKMOS (kneeling to Agmar) Master, I am childless, and I....

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Trouble us not now. It is the hour at which the gods are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: accustomed to speak to the gods in the language of the gods, and if
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Man heard us he would guess the futility of his destiny, which were
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not well for Man. Begone! Begone! (Exeunt all but one who lingers.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eat it: the beggars rise and stretch themselves: they laugh, but Agmar

text: eats hungrily.)

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Ah, now we have come into our own.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN Now we have alms.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Master! My wise Master!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF These are the good days, the good days; and yet I have a fear.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG What do you fear? There is nothing to fear. No man is as wise as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my Master.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF I fear the gods whom we pretend to be.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG The gods?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (taking a chunk of meat from his lips) Come hither, Slag.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG (going up to him) Yes, Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Watch in the doorway while I eat. (Slag goes to the doorway)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sit in the attitude of a god. Warn me if any of the citizens approach.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (Slag sits in the doorway in the attitude of a god, back to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: audience)

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN But if we are not wise, Master?

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN O Master!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: doorway.)

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Do they believe us, master?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG (half turning his head) Someone comes. (Slag resumes his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: position.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: attitude. Enter one.)

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ONE Master, I want the god that does not eat.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR I am he.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ONE Master, my child was bitten in the throat by a death-adder at
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: noon. Spare him, Master; he still breathes, but slowly.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Is he indeed your child?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ONE He is surely my child, Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Was it your wont to thwart him in his play, while he was strong
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and well?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ONE I never thwarted him, Master.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ONE Death is the child of the gods.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Do you that never thwarted your child in his play ask this of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods?

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: play-fields of this child of the gods. (The man goes away in silence
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: not weeping.)

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Same room. A few days have elapsed. Seven thrones shaped like
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain-crags stand along the back of the stage. On these the beggars
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are lounging. The Thief is absent.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: MLAN Never had beggars such a time.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO Ah, the fruits and tender lamb!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN The Woldery wine!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG It was better to see my Master's wise devices than to have fruit
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and lamb and Woldery wine.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: MLAN Ah, when they spied on him to see if he would eat when they went
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO When they questioned him concerning the gods and Man!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN When they asked him why the gods permitted cancer!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAG Ah! My wise Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: MLAN How well his scheme has succeeded.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OOGNO How far away is hunger!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THAHN It is even like to one of last year's dreams, the trouble of a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brief night long ago.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: MLAN Ho, ho, ho, to see them pray to us!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (sternly) When we were beggars did we not speak as beggars? Did
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we not whine as they? Was not our mien beggarly?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: MLAN We were the pride of our calling.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR (sternly) Then now that we are gods let us _be_ as gods, and not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mock our worshippers.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF I think the gods _do_ mock their worshippers.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR The gods have never mocked _us_. We are above all pinnacles that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we have ever gazed at in dreams.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ULF I think that when Man is high then most of all are the gods wont
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to mock him. (Enter Thief)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF Master, I have been with those that see all and know all, I have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been with the thieves, Master. They know me for one of the craft, but
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they do not know me as being one of us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Well, well ...
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF There is danger, Master, there is great danger.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR You mean that they suspect that we are men?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF That they have long done, Master. I mean that they will know it.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then we are lost.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Then they do not know it?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF They do not know it yet, but they will know it, and we are lost.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR When will they know it?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF Three days ago they suspected us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR More than you think suspected us, but have any dared to say so?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THIEF No, Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AGMAR Then forget your fears, my thief.
