text: ACT I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time: A long time ago. SCENE: The dinner-hour on the slave-fields of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King Darniak.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (The Curtain rises upon King Argimenes, sitting upon the ground,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bowed, ragged, and dirty, gnawing a bone. He has uncouth hair and a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dishevelled beard. A battered spade lies near him. Two or three slaves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sit at back of stage eating raw cabbage-leaves. The tear-song, the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chaunt of the low-born, rises at intervals, monotonous and mournful,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: coming from distant slave-fields.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES This is a good bone; there is juice in this bone.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB I wish I were you, Argimenes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES I am not to be envied any longer. I have eaten up my
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bone.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB I wish I were you, because you have been a King. Because men
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have prostrated themselves before your feet. Because you have ridden a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: horse and worn a crown and have been called Majesty.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES When I remember that I have been a king it is very
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: terrible.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB But you are lucky to have such things in your memory as you have.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I have nothing in my memory--Once I went for a year without being
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flogged, and I remember my cleverness in contriving it--I have nothing
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: else to remember.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES It is very terrible to have been a king.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB But we have nothing who have no good memories in the past. It is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not easy for us to hope for the future here.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Have you any god?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB We may not have a god because he might make us brave and we might
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: kill our guards. He might make a miracle and give us swords.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Ah, you have no hope then.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB I have a little hope. Hush, and I will tell you a secret--The
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King's great dog is ill and like to die. They will throw him to us. We
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall have beautiful bones then.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Ah! Bones.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Yes. That is what _I_ hope for. And have _you_ no other hope? Do
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you not hope that your nation will arise some day and rescue you
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and cast off the king and hang him up by his thumbs from the palace
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gateway?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES No. I have no other hope, for my god was cast down in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the temple and broken into three pieces on the day that they surprised
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: us and took me sleeping. But will they throw him to us? Will so
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: honourable a brute as the King's dog be thrown to us?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB When he is dead his honours are taken away. Even the King when he
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is dead is given to the worms. Then why should not his dog be thrown
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to us?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES We are not worms!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB You do not understand, Argimenes. The worms are little and free,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while we are big and enslaved. I did not say we were worms, but we are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _like_ worms, and if they have the King when he is dead, why then--
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Tell me more of the King's dog. Are there big bones on
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Ay, he is a big dog--a high, big, black one.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES You know him then?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB O yes, I know him. I know him well. I was beaten once because of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him, twenty-five strokes from the treble whips, two men beating me.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES How did they beat you because of the King's dog?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB They beat me because I spoke to him without making obeisance. He
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was coming dancing alone over the slave-fields and I spoke to him. He
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was a friendly great dog, and I spoke to him and patted his head, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: did not make obeisance.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES And they saw you do it?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Yes, the slave-guard saw me. They came and seized me at once and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bound my arms. The great dog wanted me to speak to him again, but I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was hurried away.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES You should have made obeisance.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB The great dog seemed so friendly that I forgot he was the King's
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great dog.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES But tell me more. Was he hurt, or is it a sickness?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB They say that it is a sickness.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Ah. Then he will grow thin if he does not die soon. If
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it had been a hurt!--but we should not complain. I complain more often
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than you do because I had not learned to submit while I was yet young.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB If your beautiful memories do not please you, you should hope
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more. I wish I had your memories. I should not trouble to hope then.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It is very hard to hope.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES There will be nothing more to hope for when we have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eaten the King's dog.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Why you might find gold in the earth while you were digging. Then
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you might bribe the commander of the guard to lend you his sword; we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would all follow you if you had a sword. Then we might take the King
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and bind him and lay him on the ground and fasten his tongue outside
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his mouth with thorns and put honey on it and sprinkle honey near.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the grey ants would come from one of their big mounds. My father
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found gold once when he was digging.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES (pointedly) Did your father free himself?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB No. Because the King's Overseer found him looking at the gold and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: killed him. But he would have freed himself if he could have bribed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the guard. (A prophet walks across the stage attended by two guards.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAVES He is going to the King. He is going to the King.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB He is going to the King.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Going to prophesy good things to the King. It is easy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to prophesy good things to a king, and be rewarded when the good
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things come. What else should come to a king? A prophet! a prophet! (A
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deep bell tolls slowly. King Argimenes and Zarb pick up their spades
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at once, and the old slaves at the back of the stage go down on their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knees immediately and grub in the soil with their hands. The white
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beard of the oldest trails in the dirt as he works. King Argimenes
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: digs.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES What is the name of that song that we always sing? I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like the song.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB It has no name. It is our song. There is no other song.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Once there were other songs. Has this no name?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB I think the soldiers have a name for it.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES What do the soldiers call it?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB The soldiers call it the tear-song, the chaunt of the low-born.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES It is a good song. I could sing no other now. (Zarb
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: moves away digging.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES (to himself as his spade touches something in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth.) Metal! (Feels with his spade again.) Gold perhaps!--It is of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: no use here. (uncovers earth leisurely. Suddenly he drops on his knees
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and works excitedly in the earth with his hands. Then very slowly,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still kneeling, he lifts, lying flat on his hands, a long greenish
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword, his eyes intent on it. About the level of his uplifted forehead
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he holds it, still flat on both hands, and addresses it thus:)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: O holy and blessed thing. (Then he lowers it slowly till his hands
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rest on his knees, and looking all the while at the sword.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Three years ago tomorrow King Darniak spat at me,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: having taken my kingdom from me. Three times in that year I was
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flogged, with twelve stripes, with seventeen stripes, and with twenty
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stripes. A year and eleven months ago, come Moon-day, the King's
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Overseer struck me in the face, and nine times in that year he called
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me dog. For one month two weeks and a day I was yoked with a bullock
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and pulled a rounded stone all day over the paths, except while we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were fed. I was flogged twice that year--with eighteen stripes and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with ten stripes. This year the roof of the slave-sty has fallen in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and King Darniak will not repair it. Five weeks ago one of his queens
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: laughed at me as she came across the slave-fields. I was flogged again
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this year and with thirteen stripes, and twelve times they have called
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me dog. And these things they have done to a king, and a king of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: house of Ithara. (He listens attentively for a moment, then buries
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword again and pats the earth over it with his hands, then digs
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again. The old slaves do not see him: their faces are to the earth.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (Enter the King's Overseer carrying a whip. The slaves and King
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Argimenes kneel with their foreheads to the ground as he passes across
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the stage. Exit the King's Overseer.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES (kneeling, hands outspread downwards.) O warrior
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spirit, wherever thou wanderest, whoever be thy gods; whether they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: punish thee or whether they bless thee; O kingly spirit that once laid
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: here this sword, behold I pray to thee having no gods to pray to, for
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the god of my nation was broken in three by night. Mine arm is stiff
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with three years' slavery and remembers not the sword. But guide thy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword till I have slain six men and armed the strongest slaves, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thou shalt have the sacrifice every year of a hundred goodly oxen. And
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I will build in Ithara a temple to thy memory wherein all that enter
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in shall remember thee, so shalt thou be honoured and envied among the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dead, for the dead are very jealous of remembrance. Aye, though thou
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wert a robber that took men's lives unrighteously, yet shall rare
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spices smoulder in thy temple and little maidens sing and new-plucked
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flowers deck the solemn aisles; and priests shall go about it ringing
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bells that thy soul shall find repose. O but it has a good blade this
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old green sword; thou wouldst not like to see it miss its mark (if the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dead see at all, as wise men teach,) thou wouldst not like to see it
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: go thirsting into the air; so huge a sword should find its marrowy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bone. (Extending his right hand upward.) Come into my right arm, O
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ancient spirit, O unknown warrior's soul. And if thou hast the ear of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: any gods, speak there against Illuriel, god of King Darniak. (He rises
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and goes on digging. Re-enter the King's Overseer.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE KING'S OVERSEER So you have been praying.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES (kneeling) No, Master.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE KING'S OVERSEER The slave-guard saw you. (Strikes him) It is not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lawful for a slave to pray.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES I did but pray to Illuriel to make me a good slave, to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: teach me to dig well and to pull the rounded stone, and to make me not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to die when the food is scarce, but to be a good slave to my master,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the great King.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE KING'S OVERSEER Who art thou to pray to Illuriel? Dogs may not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pray to an immortal god. (Exit. Zarb comes back, digging.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES (digging) Zarb.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB (also digging) Do not look at me when you speak. The guards are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: watching us. Look at your digging.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES How do the guards know we are speaking because we look
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at one another?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB You are very witless. Of course they know.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Zarb.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB What is it?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES How many guards are there in sight?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB There are six of them over there. They are watching us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Are there other guards in sight of these six guards?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB No.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES How do you know?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Because whenever their officer leaves them they sit upon the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ground and play with dice.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES How does that show that there are not another six in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sight of them?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB How witless you are, Argimenes. Of course it shows there are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not. Because, if there were, another officer would see them, and their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thumbs would be cut off.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Ah. (a pause.) Zarb. (a pause) Would the slaves follow
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me if I tried to kill the guards?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB No, Argimenes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Why would they not follow me?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Because you look like a slave. They will never follow a slave,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because they are slaves themselves, and know how mean a creature is a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slave. If you looked like a king they would follow you.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES But I am a king. They know that I am a king.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB It is better to look like a king. It is looks that they would go
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES If I had a sword would they follow me? A beautiful huge
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword of bronze.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB I wish I could think of things like that. It is because you were
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once a king that you can think of a sword of bronze. I tried to hope
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once that I should some day fight the guards, but I couldn't picture a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword, I couldn't imagine it; I could only picture whips.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES Dig a little nearer, Zarb. (They both edge closer.) I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have found a very old sword in the earth. It is not a sword such as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: common soldiers wear. A king must have worn it, and an angry king. It
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: must have done fearful things; there are little dints in it. Perhaps
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there was a battle here long ago where all were slain, and perhaps
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that king died last and buried his sword, but the great birds
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: swallowed him.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB You have been thinking too much of the King's dog, Argimenes, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that has made you hungry, and hunger has driven you mad.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES I _have_ found such a sword. (A pause.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Why--then you will wear a purple cloak again, and sit on a great
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: throne, and ride a prancing horse, and we shall call you Majesty.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES I shall break a long fast first and drink much water,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and sleep. But will the slaves follow me?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB You will _make_ them follow you if you have a sword. Yet is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Illuriel a very potent god. They say that none have prevailed against
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King Darniak's dynasty so long as Illuriel stood. Once an enemy cast
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Illuriel into the river and overthrew the dynasty, but a fisherman
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found him again and set him up, and the enemy was driven out and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dynasty returned.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES If Illuriel could be cast down as my god was cast down
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: perhaps King Darniak could be overcome as I was overcome in my sleep?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB If Illuriel were cast down all the people would utter a cry and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flee away. It would be a fearful portent.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: KING ARGIMENES How many men are there in the armoury at the palace?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB There are ten men in the palace armoury when all the slave-guards
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are out. (They dig awhile in silence.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB The officer of the slave-guard has gone away--they are playing
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with dice now. (Zarb throws down his spade and stretches his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arms)--The man with the big beard has won again, he is very nimble
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with his thumbs--They are playing again, but it is getting dark, I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cannot clearly see.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (King Argimenes furtively uncovers the sword, he picks it up and grips
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it in his hand.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB Majesty! (King Argimenes crouches and steals away towards the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slave-guard.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB (to the other slaves) Argimenes has found a terrible sword and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: has gone to slay the slave-guard. It is not a common sword, it is some
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: king's sword.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: AN OLD SLAVE Argimenes will be dreadfully flogged. We shall hear him
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cry all night. His cries will frighten us, and we shall not sleep.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB No! no! The guards flog poor slaves, but Argimenes had an angry
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: look. The guards will be afraid when they see him look so angry and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: see his terrible sword. It was a huge sword, and he looked very angry.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He will bring us the swords of the slave-guard. We must prostrate
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ourselves before him and kiss his feet or he will be angry with us
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: too.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: OLD SLAVE Will Argimenes give me a sword?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB He will have swords for six of us if he slays the slave-guard.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Yes, he will give you a sword.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SLAVE A sword! No, no, I must not; the King would kill me if he found
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that I had a sword.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SECOND SLAVE (slowly, as one who develops an idea) If the King found
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that I had a sword, why then it would be an evil day for the King.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (They all look off left.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB I think that they are playing at dice again.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: FIRST SLAVE I do not see Argimenes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB No, because he was crouching as he walked. The slave-guard is on
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sky-line.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SECOND SLAVE What is that dark shadow behind the slave-guard?
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB It is too still to be Argimenes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: SECOND SLAVE Look! It moves.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ZARB The evening is too dark, I cannot see. (They continue to gaze
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the gathering darkness. They raise themselves on their knees and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crane their necks. Nobody speaks. Then from their lips and from others
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: further off goes up a long deep Oh! It is like the sound that goes up
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the grand stand when a horse falls at a fence, or in England like
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the first exclamation of the crowd at a great cricket match when a man
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is caught in the slips.)
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE FALL OF BABBULKUND
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I said: 'I will arise now and see Babbulkund, City of Marvel. She is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of one age with the earth; the stars are her sisters. Pharaohs of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old time coming conquering from Araby first saw her, a solitary
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain in the desert, and cut the mountain into towers and terraces.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They destroyed one of the hills of God, but they made Babbulkund. She
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is carven, not built; her palaces are one with her terraces, there is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: neither join nor cleft. Hers is the beauty of the youth of the world.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: She deemeth herself to be the middle of Earth, and hath four gates
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: facing outward to the Nations. There sits outside her eastern gate a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: colossal god of stone. His face flushes with the lights of dawn. When
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the morning sunlight warms his lips they part a little, and he giveth
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: utterance to the words 'Oon Oom,' and the language is long since dead
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in which he speaks, and all his worshippers are gathered to their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tombs, so that none knoweth what the words portend that he uttereth at
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dawn. Some say that he greets the sun as one god greets another in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: language thereof, and others say that he proclaims the day, and others
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that he uttereth warning. And at every gate is a marvel not credible
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: until beholden.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I gathered three friends and said to them: 'We are what we have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen and known. Let us journey now and behold Babbulkund, that our
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: minds may be beautified with it and our spirits made holier.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So we took ship and travelled over the lifting sea, and remembered not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things done in the towns we knew, but laid away the thoughts of them
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like soiled linen and put them by, and dreamed of Babbulkund.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But when we came to the land of which Babbulkund is the abiding glory,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we hired a caravan of camels and Arab guides, and passed southwards
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the afternoon on the three days' journey through the desert that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: should bring us to the white walls of Babbulkund. And the heat of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sun shone upon us out of the bright grey sky, and the heat of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert beat up at us from below.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: About sunset we halted and tethered our horses, while the Arabs
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unloaded the provisions from the camels and prepared a fire out of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dry scrub, for at sunset the heat of the desert departs from it
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suddenly, like a bird. Then we saw a traveller approaching us on a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: camel coming from the south. When he was come near we said to him:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Come and encamp among us, for in the desert all men are brothers, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we will give thee meat to eat and wine, or, if thou art bound by thy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: faith, we will give thee some other drink that is not accursed by the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophet.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The traveller seated himself beside us on the sand, and crossed his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: legs and answered:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Hearken, and I will tell you of Babbulkund, City of Marvel.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund stands just below the meeting of the rivers, where Oonrana,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: River of Myth, flows into the Waters of Fable, even the old stream
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Plegathanees. These, together, enter her northern gate rejoicing. Of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old they flowed in the dark through the Hill that Nehemoth, the first
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Pharaohs, carved into the City of Marvel. Sterile and desolate they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: float far through the desert, each in the appointed cleft, with life
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon neither bank, but give birth in Babbulkund to the sacred purple
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: garden whereof all nations sing. Thither all the bees come on a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pilgrimage at evening by a secret way of the air. Once, from his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: twilit kingdom, which he rules equally with the sun, the moon saw
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and loved Babbulkund, clad with her purple garden; and the moon wooed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund, and she sent him weeping away, for she is more beautiful
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than all her sisters the stars. Her sisters come to her at night into
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her maiden chamber. Even the gods speak sometimes of Babbulkund, clad
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with her purple garden. Listen, for I perceive by your eyes that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ye have not seen Babbulkund; there is a restlessness in them and an
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unappeased wonder. Listen. In the garden whereof I spoke there is a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lake that hath no twin or fellow in the world; there is no companion
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for it among all the lakes. The shores of it are of glass, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bottom of it. In it are great fish having golden and scarlet scales,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and they swim to and fro. Here it is the wont of the eighty-second
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth (who rules in the city to-day) to come, after the dusk has
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fallen, and sit by the lake alone, and at this hour eight hundred
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slaves go down by steps through caverns into vaults beneath the lake.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Four hundred of them carrying purple lights march one behind the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: other, from east to west, and four hundred carrying green lights
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: march one behind the other, from west to east. The two lines cross and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: re-cross each other in and out as the slaves go round and round, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the fearful fish flash up and down and to and fro.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But upon that traveller speaking night descended, solemn and cold, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we wrapped ourselves in our blankets and lay down upon the sand in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sight of the astral sisters of Babbulkund. And all that night the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert said many things, softly and in a whisper, but I knew not what
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he said. Only the sand knew and arose and was troubled and lay down
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, and the wind knew. Then, as the hours of the night went by,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: these two discovered the foot-tracks wherewith we had disturbed the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: holy desert, and they troubled over them and covered them up; and then
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the wind lay down and the sand rested. Then the wind rose again and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sand danced. This they did many times. And all the while the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert whispered what I shall not know.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then I slept awhile and awoke just before sunrise, very cold. Suddenly
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sun leapt up and flamed upon our faces; we all threw off our
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: blankets and stood up. Then we took food, and afterwards started
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: southwards, and in the heat of the day rested, and afterwards pushed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on again. And all the while the desert remained the same, like a dream
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that will not cease to trouble a tired sleeper.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And often travellers passed us in the desert, coming from the City of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Marvel, and there was a light and a glory in their eyes from having
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen Babbulkund. That evening, at sunset, another traveller neared us,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and we hailed him, saying:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Wilt thou eat and drink with us, seeing that all men are brothers in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the desert?'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he descended from his camel and sat by us and said:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'When morning shines on the colossus Neb and Neb speaks, at once the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: musicians of King Nehemoth in Babbulkund awake.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'At first their fingers wander over their golden harps, or they stroke
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: idly their violins. Clearer and clearer the note of each instrument
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ascends like larks arising from the dew, till suddenly they all blend
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: together and a new melody is born. Thus, every morning, the musicians
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of King Nehemoth make a new marvel in the City of Marvel; for these
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are no common musicians, but masters of melody, raided by conquest
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long since, and carried away in ships from the Isles of Song. And, at
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sound of the music, Nehemoth awakes in the eastern chamber of his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: palace, which is carved in the form of a great crescent, four miles
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long, on the northern side of the city. Full in the windows of its
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eastern chamber the sun rises, and full in the windows of its western
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chamber the sun sets.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'When Nehemoth awakes he summons slaves who bring a palanquin with
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bells, which the King enters, having lightly robed. Then the slaves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: run and bear him to the onyx Chamber of the Bath, with the sound of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: small bells ringing as they run. And when Nehemoth emerges thence,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bathed and annointed, the slaves run on with their ringing palanquin
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and bear him to the Orient Chamber of Banquets, where the King takes
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the first meal of the day. Thence, through the great white corridor
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whose windows all face sunwards, Nehemoth, in his palanquin, passes
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on to the Audience Chamber of Embassies from the North, which is all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: decked with Northern wares.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'All about it are ornaments of amber from the North and carven
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chalices of the dark brown Northern crystal, and on its floors lie
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: furs from Baltic shores.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'In adjoining chambers are stored the wonted food of the hardy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Northern men, and the strong wine of the North, pale but terrible.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Therein the King receives barbarian princes from the frigid lands.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thence the slaves bear him swiftly to the Audience Chamber of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Embassies from the East, where the walls are of turquoise, studded
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the rubies of Ceylon, where the gods are the gods of the East,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where all the hangings have been devised in the gorgeous heart of Ind,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and where all the carvings have been wrought with the cunning of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: isles. Here, if a caravan hath chanced to have come in from Ind or
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from Cathay, it is the King's wont to converse awhile with Moguls or
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Mandarins, for from the East come the arts and knowledge of the world,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the converse of their people is polite. Thus Nehemoth passes on
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the other Audience Chambers & receives, perhaps, some Sheihks
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the Arab folk who have crossed the great desert from the West, or
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: receives an embassy sent to do him homage from the shy jungle people
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the South. And all the while the slaves with the ringing palanquin
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: run westwards, following the sun, and ever the sun shines straight
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the chamber where Nehemoth sits, and all the while the music from
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one or other of his bands of musicians comes tinkling to his ears.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But when the middle of the day draws near, the slaves run to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cool grooves that lie along the verandahs on the northern side of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: palace, forsaking the sun, and as the heat overcomes the genius of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: musicians, one by one their hands fall from their instruments, till at
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last all melody ceases. At this moment Nehemoth falls asleep, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slaves put the palanquin down and lie down beside it. At this hour the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city becomes quite still, and the palace of Nehemoth and the tombs of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Pharaohs of old face to the sunlight, all alike in silence. Even
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the jewellers in the market-place, selling gems to princes, cease from
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their bargaining and cease to sing; for in Babbulkund the vendor of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rubies sings the song of the ruby, and the vendor of sapphires sings
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the song of the sapphire, and each stone hath its song, so that a man,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by his song, proclaims and makes known his wares.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'But all these sounds cease at the meridian hour, the jewellers in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: market-place lie down in what shadow they can find, and the princes
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: go back to the cool places in their palaces, and a great hush in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gleaming air hangs over Babbulkund. But in the cool of the late
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: afternoon, one of the King's musicians will awake from dreaming of his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: home and will pass his fingers, perhaps, over the strings of his harp
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and, with the music, some memory may arise of the wind in the glens of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mountains that stand in the Isles of Song. Then the musician will
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wrench great cries out of the soul of his harp for the sake of the old
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: memory, and his fellows will awake and all make a song of home, woven
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of sayings told in the harbour when the ships came in, and of tales in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the cottages about the people of old time. One by one the other bands
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of musicians will take up the song, and Babbulkund, City of Marvel,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will throb with this marvel anew. Just now Nehemoth awakes, the slaves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leap to their feet and bear the palanquin to the outer side of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great crescent palace between the south and the west, to behold the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sun again. The palanquin, with its ringing bells, goes round once
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more; the voices of the jewellers sing again in the market-place
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the song of the emerald, the song of the sapphire; men talk on the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: housetops, beggars wail in the streets, the musicians bend to their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: work, all the sounds blend together into one murmur, the voice of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund speaking at evening. Lower and lower sinks the sun, till
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth, following it, comes with his panting slaves to the great
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purple garden of which surely thine own country has its songs, from
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wherever thou art come.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'There he alights from his palanquin and goes up to a throne of ivory
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: set in the garden's midst, facing full westwards, and sits there
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alone, long regarding the sunlight until it is quite gone. At this
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hour trouble comes into the face of Nehemoth. Men have heard him
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: muttering at the time of sunset: 'Even I too, even I too.' Thus do
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King Nehemoth and the sun make their glorious ambits about Babbulkund.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'A little later, when the stars come out to envy the beauty of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: City of Marvel, the King walks to another part of the garden and sits
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in an alcove of opal all alone by the marge of the sacred lake. This
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is the lake whose shores and floors are of glass, which is lit
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from beneath by slaves with purple lights and with green lights
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: intermingling, and is one of the seven wonders of Babbulkund. Three of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the wonders are in the city's midst and four are at her gates. There
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is the lake, of which I tell thee, and the purple garden of which I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have told thee and which is a wonder even to the stars, and there is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ong Zwarba, of which I shall tell thee also. And the wonders at the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gates are these. At the eastern gate Neb. And at the northern gate
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the wonder of the river and the arches, for the River of Myth, which
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: becomes one with the Waters of Fable in the desert outside the city,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: floats under a gate of pure gold, rejoicing, and under many arches
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fantastically carven that are one with either bank. The marvel at the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: western gate is the marvel of Annolith and the dog Voth. Annolith sits
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: outside the western gate facing towards the city. He is higher than
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: any of the towers or palaces, for his head was carved from the summit
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the old hill; he hath two eyes of sapphire wherewith he regards
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund, and the wonder of the eyes is that they are to-day in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: same sockets wherein they glowed when first the world began, only the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marble that covered them has been carven away and the light of day let
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in and the sight of the envious stars. Larger than a lion is the dog
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Voth beside him; every hair is carven upon the back of Voth, his war
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hackles are erected and his teeth are bared. All the Nehemoths have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worshipped the god Annolith, but all their people pray to the dog
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Voth, for the law of the land is that none but a Nehemoth may worship
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the god Annolith. The marvel at the southern gate is the marvel of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle, for he comes with all his wild untravelled sea of darkness and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: trees and tigers and sunward-aspiring orchids right through a marble
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gate in the city wall and enters the city, and there widens and holds
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a space in its midst of many miles across. Moreover, he is older than
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the City of Marvel, for he dwelt long since in one of the valleys
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the mountain which Nehemoth, first of Pharaohs, carved into
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Now the opal alcove in which the King sits at evening by the lake
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stands at the edge of the jungle, and the climbing orchids of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle have long since crept from their homes through clefts of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: opal alcove, lured by the lights of the lake, and now bloom there
