title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: exultingly. Near to this alcove are the hareems of Nehemoth.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'The King hath four hareems--one for the stalwart women from the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains to the north, one for the dark and furtive jungle women, one
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the desert women that have wandering souls and pine in Babbulkund,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and one for the princesses of his own kith, whose brown cheeks blush
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the blood of ancient Pharaohs and who exult with Babbulkund in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her surpassing beauty, and who know nought of the desert or the jungle
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: or the bleak hills to the north. Quite unadorned and clad in simple
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: garments go all the kith of Nehemoth, for they know well that he grows
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weary of pomp. Unadorned all save one, the Princess Linderith, who
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weareth Ong Zwarba and the three lesser gems of the sea. Such a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stone is Ong Zwarba that there are none like it even in the turban of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth nor in all the sanctuaries of the sea. The same god that made
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Linderith made long ago Ong Zwarba; she and Ong Zwarba shine together
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with one light, and beside this marvellous stone gleam the three
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lesser ones of the sea.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Now when the King sitteth in his opal alcove by the sacred lake with
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the orchids blooming around him all sounds are become still. The sound
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the tramping of the weary slaves as they go round and round never
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comes to the surface. Long since the musicians sleep, and their hands
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have fallen dumb upon their instruments, and the voices in the city
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have died away. Perhaps a sigh of one of the desert women has become
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: half a song, or on a hot night in summer one of the women of the hills
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sings softly a song of snow; all night long in the midst of the purple
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: garden sings one nightingale; all else is still; the stars that look
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on Babbulkund arise and set, the cold unhappy moon drifts lonely
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through them, the night wears on; at last the dark figure of Nehemoth,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eighty-second of his line, rises and moves stealthily away.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The traveller ceased to speak. For a long time the clear stars,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sisters of Babbulkund, had shone upon him speaking, the desert wind
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had arisen and whispered to the sand, and the sand had long gone
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: secretly to and fro; none of us had moved, none of us had fallen
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: asleep, not so much from wonder at his tale as from the thought that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we ourselves in two days' time should see that wondrous city. Then we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wrapped our blankets around us and lay down with our feet towards the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: embers of our fire and instantly were asleep, and in our dreams we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: multiplied the fame of the City of Marvel.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The sun arose and flamed upon our faces, and all the desert glinted
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with its light. Then we stood up and prepared the morning meal, and,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when we had eaten, the traveller departed. And we commended his soul
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the god of the land whereto he went, of the land of his home to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: northward, and he commended our souls to the god of the people of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the land wherefrom we had come. Then a traveller overtook us going on
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: foot; he wore a brown cloak that was all in rags and he seemed to have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been walking all night, and he walked hurriedly but appeared weary, so
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we offered him food and drink, of which he partook thankfully. When
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we asked him where he was going, he answered 'Babbulkund.' Then we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: offered him a camel upon which to ride, for we said, 'We also go to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund.' But he answered strangely: 'Nay, pass on before me, for
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it is a sore thing never to have seen Babbulkund, having lived while
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: yet she stood. Pass on before me and behold her, and then flee away at
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once, returning northward.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then, though we understood him not, we left him, for he was insistent,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and passed on our journey southwards through the desert, and we came
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before the middle of the day to an oasis of palm trees standing by a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well and there we gave water to the haughty camels and replenished our
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: water-bottles and soothed our eyes with the sight of green things and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tarried for many hours in the shade. Some of the men slept, but of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: those that remained awake each man sang softly the songs of his own
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: country, telling of Babbulkund. When the afternoon was far spent
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we travelled a little way southwards, and went on through the cool
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening until the sun fell low and we encamped, and as we sat in our
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: encampment the man in rags overtook us, having travelled all the day,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and we gave him food and drink again, and in the twilight he spoke,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saying:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I am the servant of the Lord the God of my people and I go to do his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: work on Babbulkund. She is the most beautiful city in the world;
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there hath been none like her, even the stars of God go envious of her
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beauty. She is all white, yet with streaks of pink that pass through
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her streets and houses like flames in the white mind of a sculptor,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like desire in Paradise. She hath been carved of old out of a holy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hill, no slaves wrought the City of Marvel, but artists toiling at the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: work they loved. They took no pattern from the houses of men, but
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: each man wrought what his inner eye had seen and carved in marble the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: visions of his dream. All over the roof of one of the palace chambers
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: winged lions flit like bats, the size of every one is the size of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lions of God, and the wings are larger than any wing created; they are
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one above the other more than a man can number, they are all carven
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of one block of marble, the chamber itself is hollowed from it,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and it is borne aloft upon the carven branches of a grove of clustered
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tree-ferns wrought by the hand of some jungle mason that loved the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tall fern well. Over the River of Myth, which is one with the Waters
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Fable, go bridges, fashioned like the wisteria tree and like the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drooping laburnum, and a hundred others of wonderful devices, the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desire of the souls of masons a long while dead. Oh! very beautiful is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: white Babbulkund, very beautiful she is, but proud; and the Lord the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: God of my people hath seen her in her pride, and looking towards
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her hath seen the prayers of Nehemoth going up to the abomination
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Annolith, and all the people following after Voth. She is very
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful, Babbulkund; alas that I may not bless her. I could live
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: always on one of her inner terraces looking on the mysterious jungle
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in her midst and the heavenward faces of the orchids that, clambering
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the darkness, behold the sun. I could love Babbulkund with a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great love, yet am I the servant of the Lord the God of my people,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the King hath sinned unto the abomination Annolith, and the people
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lust exceedingly for Voth. Alas for thee, Babbulkund, alas that I may
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not even now turn back, for to-morrow I must prophesy against thee
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and cry out against thee, Babbulkund. But ye travellers that have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: entreated me hospitably, rise and pass on with your camels, for I can
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tarry no longer, and I go to do the work on Babbulkund of the Lord the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: God of my people. Go now and see the beauty of Babbulkund before I cry
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out against her, and then flee swiftly northwards.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: A smouldering fragment fell in upon our camp fire and sent a strange
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: light into the eyes of the man in rags. He rose at once, and his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tattered cloak swirled up with him like a great wing; he said no more,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but turned round from us instantly southwards, and strode away into
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the darkness towards Babbulkund. Then a hush fell upon our encampment,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the smell of the tobacco of those lands arose. When the last flame
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: died down in our camp fire I fell asleep, but my rest was troubled by
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shifting dreams of doom.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Morning came, and our guides told us that we should come to the city
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ere nightfall. Again we passed southwards through the changeless
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert; sometimes we met travellers coming from Babbulkund, with the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beauty of its marvels still fresh in their eyes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When we encamped near the middle of the day we saw a great number of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people on foot coming towards us running, from the southwards. These
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we hailed when they were come near, saying, 'What of Babbulkund?'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They answered: 'We are not of the race of the people of Babbulkund,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but were captured in youth and taken away from the hills that are to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the northward. Now we have all seen in visions of the stillness the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lord the God of our people calling to us from His hills, and therefore
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we all flee northward. But in Babbulkund King Nehemoth hath been
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: troubled in the nights by unkingly dreams of doom, and none may
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: interpret what the dreams portend. Now this is the dream that King
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth dreamed on the first night of his dreaming. He saw move
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the stillness a bird all black, and beneath the beatings of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his wings Babbulkund gloomed and darkened; and after him flew a bird
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all white, beneath the beatings of whose wings Babbulkund gleamed and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shone; and there flew by four more birds alternately black and white.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And, as the black ones passed Babbulkund darkened, and when the white
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ones appeared her streets and houses shone. But after the sixth bird
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there came no more, and Babbulkund vanished from her place, and there
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was only the empty desert where she had stood, and the rivers Oonrana
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and Plegathanees mourning alone. Next morning all the prophets of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King gathered before their abominations and questioned them of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dream, and the abominations spake not. But when the second night
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stepped down from the halls of God, dowered with many stars, King
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth dreamed again; and in this dream King Nehemoth saw four birds
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only, black and white alternately as before. And Babbulkund darkened
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again as the black ones passed, and shone when the white came by; only
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: after the four birds came no more, and Babbulkund vanished from her
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: place, leaving only the forgetful desert and the mourning rivers.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Still the abominations spake not, and none could interpret the dream.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And when the third night came forth from the divine halls of her home
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dowered like her sisters, again King Nehemoth dreamed. And he saw a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bird all black go by again, beneath whom Babbulkund darkened, and then
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a white bird and Babbulkund shone; and after them came no more,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and Babbulkund passed away. And the golden day appeared, dispelling
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreams, and still the abominations were silent, and the King's
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophets answered not to portend the omen of the dream. One prophet
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only spake before the King, saying: 'The sable birds, O King, are the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nights, and the white birds are the days,...' This thing the King had
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feared, and he arose and smote the prophet with his sword, whose soul
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went crying away and had to do no more with nights and days.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'It was last night that the King dreamed his third dream, and this
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: morning we fled away from Babbulkund. A great heat lies over it, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the orchids of the jungle droop their heads. All night long the women
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the hareem of the North have wailed horribly for their hills. A
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fear hath fallen upon the city, and a boding. Twice hath Nehemoth gone
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to worship Annolith, and all the people have prostrated themselves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before Voth. Thrice the horologers have looked into the great crystal
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: globe wherein are foretold all happenings to be, and thrice the globe
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was blank. Yea, though they went a fourth time yet was no vision
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: revealed; and the people's voice is hushed in Babbulkund.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Soon the travellers arose and pushed on northwards again, leaving us
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wondering. Through the heat of the day we rested as well as we might,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but the air was motionless and sultry and the camels ill at ease. The
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Arabs said that it boded a desert storm, and that a great wind would
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arise full of sand. So we arose in the afternoon, and travelled
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: swiftly, hoping to come to shelter before the storm. And the air
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: burned in the stillness between the baked desert and the glaring sky.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly a wind arose out of the South, blowing from Babbulkund, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sand lifted and went by in great shapes, all whispering. And the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind blew violently, and wailed as it blew, and hundreds of sandy
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shapes went towering by, and there were little cries among them and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sounds of a passing away. Soon the wind sank quite suddenly, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: its cries died, and the panic ceased among the driven sands. And when
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the storm departed the air was cool, and the terrible sultriness and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the boding were passed away, and the camels had ease among them. And
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Arabs said that the storm which was to be had been, as was willed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of old by God.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The sun set and the gloaming came, and we neared the junction
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Oonrana and Plegathanees, but in the darkness discerned not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund. We pushed on hurriedly to reach the city ere nightfall,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and came to the junction of the River of Myth where he meets with the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Waters of Fable, and still saw not Babbulkund. All round us lay the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sand and rocks of the unchanging desert, save to the southwards where
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the jungle stood with its orchids facing skywards. Then we perceived
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that we had arrived too late, and that her doom had come to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund; and by the river in the empty desert on the sand the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man in rags was seated, with his face hidden in his hands, weeping
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bitterly.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thus passed away in the hour of her iniquities before Annolith, in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: two thousand and thirty-second year of her being, in the six thousand
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and fiftieth year of the building of the World, Babbulkund, City of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Marvel, sometime called by those that hated her City of the Dog, but
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hourly mourned in Araby and Ind and wide through jungle and desert;
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leaving no memorial in stone to show that she had been, but remembered
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with an abiding love, in spite of the anger of God, by all that knew
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her beauty, whereof still they sing.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE SPHINX AT GIZEH
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I saw the other day the Sphinx's painted face.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: She had painted her face in order to ogle Time.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he has spared no other painted face in all the world but hers.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Delilah was younger than she, and Delilah is dust.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time hath loved nothing but this worthless painted face.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I do not care that she is ugly, nor that she has painted her face, so
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that she only lure his secret from Time.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time dallies like a fool at her feet when he should be smiting cities.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time never wearies of her silly smile.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There are temples all about her that he has forgotten to spoil.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I saw an old man go by and Time never touched him.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time that has carried away the seven gates of Thebes!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: She has tried to bind him with ropes of eternal sand, she had hoped to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: oppress him with the Pyramids.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He lies there in the sun with his foolish hair all spread about her
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: paws.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: If she ever learns his secret we will put out his eyes, so that he
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall find no more our beautiful things--there are lovely gates in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Florence that I fear he will carry away.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: We have tried to bind him with song and with old customs, but they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only held him for a little while, and he has always smitten us and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mocked us.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When he is blind he shall dance to us and make sport.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Great clumsy Time shall stumble and dance, who liked to kill little
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: children and can hurt even the daisies no longer.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then shall our children laugh at him who slew Babylon's winged bulls
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and smote great numbers of the elves and fairies, when he is shorn of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his hours and his years.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: We will shut him up in the Pyramid of Cheops, in the great chamber
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where the sarcophagus is. Thence we will lead him out when we give our
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feasts. He shall ripen our corn for us and do menial work.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: We will kiss thy painted face, O Sphinx, if thou wilt betray to us
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And yet I fear that in his ultimate anguish he may take hold blindly
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the world and the moon and slowly pull down upon him the House of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Man.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: IDLE DAYS ON THE YANN
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So I came down through the wood to the bank of Yann and found, as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had been prophesied, the ship _Bird of the River_ about to loose her
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cable.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The captain sate cross-legged upon the white deck with his scimitar
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lying beside him in its jewelled scabbard, and the sailors toiled to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spread the nimble sails to bring the ship into the central stream of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Yann, and all the while sang ancient soothing songs. And the wind of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the evening descending cool from the snowfields of some mountainous
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: abode of distant gods came suddenly, like glad tidings to an anxious
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city, into the wing-like sails.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And so we came into the central stream, whereat the sailors lowered
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the greater sails. But I had gone to bow before the captain, and to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: inquire concerning the miracles, and appearances among men, of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: most holy gods of whatever land he had come from. And the captain
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: answered that he came from fair Belzoond, and worshipped gods that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were the least and humblest, who seldom sent the famine or the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thunder, and were easily appeased with little battles. And I told how
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I came from Ireland, which is of Europe, whereat the captain and all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sailors laughed, for they said, 'There are no such places in all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the land of dreams.' When they had ceased to mock me, I explained that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my fancy mostly dwelt in the desert of Cuppar-Nombo, about a beautiful
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: blue city called Golthoth the Damned, which was sentinelled all round
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by wolves and their shadows, and had been utterly desolate for years
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and years because of a curse which the gods once spoke in anger and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: could never since recall. And sometimes my dreams took me as far as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Pungar Vees, the red-walled city where the fountains are, which trades
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the Isles and Thul. When I said this they complimented me upon
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the abode of my fancy, saying that, though they had never seen these
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cities, such places might well be imagined. For the rest of that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening I bargained with the captain over the sum that I should pay
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him for my fare if God and the tide of Yann should bring us safely as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: far as the cliffs by the sea, which are named Bar-Wul-Yann, the Gate
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Yann.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now the sun had set, and all the colours of the world and heaven
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had held a festival with him, and slipped one by one away before the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: imminent approach of night. The parrots had all flown home to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle on either bank, the monkeys in rows in safety on high branches
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the trees were silent and asleep, the fireflies in the deeps of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forest were going up and down, and the great stars came gleaming out
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to look on the face of Yann. Then the sailors lighted lanterns and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hung them round the ship, and the light flashed out on a sudden
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and dazzled Yann, and the ducks that fed along his marshy banks all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suddenly arose, and made wide circles in the upper air, and saw the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: distant reaches of the Yann and the white mist that softly cloaked the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle, before they returned again into their marshes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And then the sailors knelt on the decks and prayed, not all together,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but five or six at a time. Side by side there kneeled down together
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: five or six, for there only prayed at the same time men of different
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: faiths, so that no god should hear two men praying to him at once.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: As soon as any one had finished his prayer, another of the same faith
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: took his place. Thus knelt the row of five or six with bended heads
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: under the fluttering sail, while the central stream of the River Yann
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: took them on towards the sea, and their prayers rose up from among the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lanterns and went towards the stars. And behind them in the after end
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the ship the helmsman prayed aloud the helmsman's prayer, which is
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prayed by all who follow his trade upon the River Yann, of whatever
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: faith they be. And the captain prayed to his little lesser gods, to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods that bless Belzoond.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I too felt that I would pray. Yet I liked not to pray to a jealous
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: God there where the frail affectionate gods whom the heathen love were
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: being humbly invoked; so I bethought me, instead, of Sheol Nugganoth,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whom the men of the jungle have long since deserted, who is now
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unworshipped and alone; and to him I prayed.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And upon us praying the night came suddenly down, as it comes upon all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men who pray at evening and upon all men who do not; yet our prayers
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comforted our own souls when we thought of the Great Night to come.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And so Yann bore us magnificently onwards, for he was elate with
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: molten snow that the Poltiades had brought him from the Hills of Hap,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the Marn and Migris were swollen full with floods; and he bore us
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in his might past Kyph and Pir, and we saw the lights of Goolunza.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Soon we all slept except the helmsman, who kept the ship in the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mid-stream of Yann.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When the sun rose the helmsman ceased to sing, for by song he cheered
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: himself in the lonely night. When the song ceased we suddenly all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: awoke, and another took the helm, and the helmsman slept.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: We knew that soon we should come to Mandaroon. We made a meal, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Mandaroon appeared. Then the captain commanded, and the sailors loosed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again the greater sails, and the ship turned and left the stream of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Yann and came into a harbour beneath the ruddy walls of Mandaroon.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then while the sailors went and gathered fruits I came alone to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gate of Mandaroon. A few huts were outside it, in which lived the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: guard. A sentinel with a long white beard was standing in the gate,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armed with a rusty pike. He wore large spectacles, which were covered
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with dust. Through the gate I saw the city. A deathly stillness was
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over all of it. The ways seemed untrodden, and moss was thick on
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: doorsteps; in the market-place huddled figures lay asleep. A scent
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of incense came wafted through the gateway, of incense and burned
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: poppies, and there was a hum of the echoes of distant bells. I said
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the sentinel in the tongue of the region of Yann, 'Why are they all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: asleep in this still city?'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He answered: 'None may ask questions in this gate for fear they wake
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the people of the city. For when the people of this city wake the gods
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will die. And when the gods die men may dream no more.' And I began to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ask him what gods that city worshipped, but he lifted his pike because
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: none might ask questions there. So I left him and went back to the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _Bird of the River_.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Certainly Mandaroon was beautiful with her white pinnacles peering
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over her ruddy walls and the green of her copper roofs.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When I came back again to the _Bird of the River_, I found the sailors
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were returned to the ship. Soon we weighed anchor, and sailed out
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, and so came once more to the middle of the river. And now the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sun was moving towards his heights, and there had reached us on the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: River Yann the song of those countless myriads of choirs that attend
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him in his progress round the world. For the little creatures that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have many legs had spread their gauze wings easily on the air, as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a man rests his elbows on a balcony, and gave jubilant, ceremonial
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: praises to the sun, or else they moved together on the air in wavering
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dances intricate and swift, or turned aside to avoid the onrush of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: some drop of water that a breeze had shaken from a jungle orchid,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chilling the air and driving it before it, as it fell whirring in its
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rush to the earth; but all the while they sang triumphantly. 'For the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: day is for us,' they said, 'whether our great and sacred father the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sun shall bring up more life like us from the marshes, or whether all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the world shall end to-night.' And there sang all those whose notes
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are known to human ears, as well as those whose far more numerous
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: notes have been never heard by man.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: To these a rainy day had been as an era of war that should desolate
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: continents during all the lifetime of a man.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And there came out also from the dark and steaming jungle to behold
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and rejoice in the Sun the huge and lazy butterflies. And they danced,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but danced idly, on the ways of the air, as some haughty queen of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: distant conquered lands might in her poverty and exile dance, in some
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: encampment of the gipsies, for the mere bread to live by, but beyond
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that would never abate her pride to dance for a fragment more.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the butterflies sung of strange and painted things, of purple
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: orchids and of lost pink cities and the monstrous colours of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle's decay. And they, too, were among those whose voices are not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: discernible by human ears. And as they floated above the river, going
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from forest to forest, their splendour was matched by the inimical
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beauty of the birds who darted out to pursue them. Or sometimes they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: settled on the white and wax-like blooms of the plant that creeps and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clambers about the trees of the forest; and their purple wings flashed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out on the great blossoms as, when the caravans go from Nurl to Thace,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gleaming silks flash out upon the snow, where the crafty merchants
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spread them one by one to astonish the mountaineers of the Hills of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Noor.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But upon men and beasts the sun sent a drowsiness. The river monsters
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: along the river's marge lay dormant in the slime. The sailors pitched
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a pavilion, with golden tassels, for the captain upon the deck, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: then went, all but the helmsman, under a sail that they had hung as an
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: awning between two masts. Then they told tales to one another, each
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of his own city or of the miracles of his god, until all were fallen
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: asleep. The captain offered me the shade of his pavilion with the gold
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tassels, and there we talked for awhile, he telling me that he was
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: taking merchandise to Perdondaris, and that he would take back to fair
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Belzoond things appertaining to the affairs of the sea. Then, as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I watched through the pavilion's opening the brilliant birds and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: butterflies that crossed and recrossed over the river, I fell asleep,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and dreamed that I was a monarch entering his capital underneath
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arches of flags, and all the musicians of the world were there,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: playing melodiously their instruments; but no one cheered.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: In the afternoon, as the day grew cooler again, I awoke and found the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: captain buckling on his scimitar, which he had taken off him while he
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rested.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now we were approaching the wide court of Astahahn, which opens
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon the river. Strange boats of antique design were chained there
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the steps. As we neared it we saw the open marble court, on three
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sides of which stood the city fronting on colonnades. And in the court
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and along the colonnades the people of that city walked with solemnity
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and care according to the rites of ancient ceremony. All in that city
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was of ancient device; the carving on the houses, which, when age
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had broken it, remained unrepaired, was of the remotest times, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the different species of gargoyle. Nothing was to be found,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whether material or custom, that was new in Astahahn. Now they took no
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: notice at all of us as we went by, but continued their processions and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ceremonies in the ancient city, and the sailors, knowing their custom,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: took no notice of them. But I called, as we came near, to one who
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stood beside the water's edge, asking him what men did in Astahahn and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what their merchandise was, and with whom they traded. He said, 'Here
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we have fettered and manacled Time, who would otherwise slay the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I asked him what gods they worshipped in that city, and he said, 'All
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: those gods whom Time has not yet slain.' Then he turned from me and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: onwards and left Astahahn.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appeared over the river, and was softly rising higher. It clutched

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
