text: though the ghosts of shipwrecked mariners were searching stealthily in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the darkness for the spirits of evil that long ago had wrecked them on
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Yann.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: As the sun sank behind the field of orchids that grew on the matted
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: summit of the jungle, the river monsters came wallowing out of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slime in which they had reclined during the heat of the day, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great beasts of the jungle came down to drink. The butterflies a while
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: since were gone to rest. In little narrow tributaries that we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: passed night seemed already to have fallen, though the sun which had
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: disappeared from us had not yet set.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now the birds of the jungle came flying home far over us, with the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sunlight glistening pink upon their breasts, and lowered their pinions
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as soon as they saw the Yann, and dropped into the trees. And the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: widgeon began to go up the river in great companies, all whistling,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and then would suddenly wheel and all go down again. And there shot by
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: us the small and arrow-like teal; and we heard the manifold cries of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flocks of geese, which the sailors told me had recently come in from
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crossing over the Lispasian ranges; every year they come by the same
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: way, close by the peak of Mluna, leaving it to the left, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain eagles know the way they come and--men say--the very hour,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and every year they expect them by the same way as soon as the snows
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have fallen upon the Northern Plains.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But soon it grew so dark that we saw these birds no more, and only
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heard the whirring of their wings, and of countless others besides,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: until they all settled down along the banks of the river, and it was
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hour when the birds of the night went forth. Then the sailors lit
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the lanterns for the night, and huge moths appeared, flapping about
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the ship, and at moments their gorgeous colours would be revealed by
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the lanterns, then they would pass into the night again, where all
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was black. And again the sailors prayed, and thereafter we supped and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slept, and the helmsman took our lives into his care.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When I awoke I found that we had indeed come to Perdondaris, that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: famous city. For there it stood upon the left of us, a city fair
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and notable, and all the more pleasant for our eyes to see after
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the jungle that was so long with us. And we were anchored by the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: market-place, and the captain's merchandise was all displayed, and a
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: merchant of Perdondaris stood looking at it. And the captain had his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: scimitar in his hand, and was beating with it in anger upon the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deck, and the splinters were flying up from the white planks; for the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: merchant had offered him a price for his merchandise that the captain
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: declared to be an insult to himself and his country's gods, whom
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he now said to be great and terrible gods, whose curses were to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be dreaded. But the merchant waved his hands, which were of great
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fatness, showing the pink palms, and swore that of himself he thought
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not at all, but only of the poor folk in the huts beyond the city to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whom he wished to sell the merchandise for as low a price as possible,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leaving no remuneration for himself. For the merchandise was mostly
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the thick toomarund carpets that in the winter keep the wind from
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the floor, and tollub which the people smoke in pipes. Therefore
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the merchant said if he offered a piffek more the poor folk must
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: go without their toomarunds when the winter came, and without their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tollub in the evenings, or else he and his aged father must starve
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: together. Thereat the captain lifted his scimitar to his own throat,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saying that he was now a ruined man, and that nothing remained to him
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but death. And while he was carefully lifting his beard with his left
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand, the merchant eyed the merchandise again, and said that rather
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than see so worthy a captain die, a man for whom he had conceived an
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: especial love when first he saw the manner in which he handled his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ship, he and his aged father should starve together and therefore he
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: offered fifteen piffeks more.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When he said this the captain prostrated himself and prayed to his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods that they might yet sweeten this merchant's bitter heart--to his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little lesser gods, to the gods that bless Belzoond.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: At last the merchant offered yet five piffeks more. Then the captain
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wept, for he said that he was deserted of his gods; and the merchant
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: also wept, for he said that he was thinking of his aged father, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of how he soon would starve, and he hid his weeping face with both
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his hands, and eyed the tollub again between his fingers. And so the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bargain was concluded, and the merchant took the toomarund and tollub,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: paying for them out of a great clinking purse. And these were packed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up into bales again, and three of the merchant's slaves carried them
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon their heads into the city. And all the while the sailors had sat
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: silent, cross-legged in a crescent upon the deck, eagerly watching the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bargain, and now a murmur of satisfaction arose among them, and they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: began to compare it among themselves with other bargains that they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had known. And I found out from them that there are seven merchants
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in Perdondaris, and that they had all come to the captain one by one
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before the bargaining began, and each had warned him privately against
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the others. And to all the merchants the captain had offered the wine
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of his own country, that they make in fair Belzoond, but could in no
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wise persuade them to it. But now that the bargain was over, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sailors were seated at the first meal of the day, the captain appeared
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among them with a cask of that wine, and we broached it with care and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all made merry together. And the captain was glad in his heart because
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he knew that he had much honour in the eyes of his men because of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the bargain that he had made. So the sailors drank the wine of their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: native land, and soon their thoughts were back in fair Belzoond and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the little neighbouring cities of Durl and Duz.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But for me the captain poured into a little glass some heavy yellow
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wine from a small jar which he kept apart among his sacred things.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thick and sweet it was, even like honey, yet there was in its heart
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a mighty, ardent fire which had authority over souls of men. It was
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: made, the captain told me, with great subtlety by the secret craft of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a family of six who lived in a hut on the mountains of Hian Min. Once
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in these mountains, he said, he followed the spoor of a bear, and he
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came suddenly on a man of that family who had hunted the same bear,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and he was at the end of a narrow way with precipice all about him,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and his spear was sticking in the bear, and the wound not fatal, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he had no other weapon. And the bear was walking towards the man, very
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slowly because his wound irked him--yet he was now very close. And
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what the captain did he would not say; but every year as soon as the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: snows are hard, and travelling is easy on the Hian Min, that man comes
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down to the market in the plains, and always leaves for the captain in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gate of fair Belzoond a vessel of that priceless secret wine.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And as I sipped the wine and the captain talked, I remembered me of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stalwart noble things that I had long since resolutely planned, and my
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soul seemed to grow mightier within me and to dominate the whole tide
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the Yann. It may be that I then slept. Or, if I did not, I do not
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: now minutely recollect every detail of that morning's occupations.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Towards evening, I awoke and wishing to see Perdondaris before we left
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the morning, and being unable to wake the captain, I went ashore
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alone. Certainly Perdondaris was a powerful city; it was encompassed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by a wall of great strength and altitude, having in it hollow ways for
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: troops to walk in, and battlements along it all the way, and fifteen
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strong towers on it in every mile, and copper plaques low down where
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men could read them, telling in all the languages of those parts of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Earth--one language on each plaque--the tale of how an army
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once attacked Perdondaris and what befel that army. Then I entered
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Perdondaris and found all the people dancing, clad in brilliant silks,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and playing on the tambang as they danced. For a fearful thunderstorm
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had terrified them while I slept, and the fires of death, they said,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had danced over Perdondaris, and now the thunder had gone leaping away
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: large and black and hideous, they said, over the distant hills, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had turned round snarling at them, showing his gleaming teeth, and had
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stamped, as he went, upon the hill-tops until they rang as though
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they had been bronze. And often and again they stopped in their merry
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dances and prayed to the God they knew not, saying, 'O, God that we
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: know not, we thank Thee for sending the thunder back to his hills.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I went on and came to the market-place, and lying there upon the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marble pavement I saw the merchant fast asleep and breathing heavily,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with his face and the palms of his hands towards the sky, and slaves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were fanning him to keep away the flies. And from the market-place I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came to a silver temple and then to a palace of onyx, and there were
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: many wonders in Perdondaris, and I would have stayed and seen them
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all, but as I came to the outer wall of the city I suddenly saw in it
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a huge ivory gate. For a while I paused and admired it, then I came
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nearer and perceived the dreadful truth. The gate was carved out of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one solid piece!
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I fled at once through the gateway and down to the ship, and even as I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ran I thought that I heard far off on the hills behind me the tramp of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the fearful beast by whom that mass of ivory was shed, who was perhaps
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: even then looking for his other tusk. When I was on the ship again I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: felt safer, and I said nothing to the sailors of what I had seen.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now the captain was gradually awakening.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now night was rolling up from the East and North, and only the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pinnacles of the towers of Perdondaris still took the fallen sunlight.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then I went to the captain and told him quietly of the thing I had
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen. And he questioned me at once about the gate, in a low voice,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that the sailors might not know; and I told him how the weight of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thing was such that it could not have been brought from afar, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: captain knew that it had not been there a year ago. We agreed that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: such a beast could never have been killed by any assault of man, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that the gate must have been a fallen tusk, and one fallen near and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: recently. Therefore he decided that it were better to flee at once; so
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he commanded, and the sailors went to the sails, and others raised the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: anchor to the deck, and just as the highest pinnacle of marble lost
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the last rays of the sun we left Perdondaris, that famous city. And
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night came down and cloaked Perdondaris and hid it from our eyes,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: which as things have happened will never see it again; for I have
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heard since that something swift and wonderful has suddenly wrecked
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Perdondaris in a day--towers, and walls, and people.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the night deepened over the River Yann, a night all white with
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stars. And with the night there rose the helmsman's song. As soon as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he had prayed he began to sing to cheer himself all through the lonely
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night. But first he prayed, praying the helmsman's prayer. And this
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is what I remember of it, rendered into English with a very feeble
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: equivalent of the rhythm that seemed so resonant in those tropic
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nights.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: To whatever god may hear.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Wherever there be sailors whether of river or sea: whether their way
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be dark or whether through storm: whether their peril be of beast or
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of rock: or from enemy lurking on land or pursuing on sea: wherever
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the tiller is cold or the helmsman stiff: wherever sailors sleep or
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: helmsmen watch: guard, guide, and return us to the old land that has
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: known us: to the far homes that we know.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: To all the gods that are.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: To whatever god may hear.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So he prayed, and there was silence. And the sailors laid them down to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rest for the night. The silence deepened, and was only broken by the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ripples of Yann that lightly touched our prow. Sometimes some monster
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: of the river coughed.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sing. And he sang the market songs of Durl and Duz, and the old
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dragon-legends of Belzoond.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tales and trifles of his city of Durl. And the songs welled up over
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the black jungle and came into the clear cold air above, and the great
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flocks that they had, and the loves that they had loved, and all the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and blankets, listening to those songs, and watching the fantastic
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flow of the river was tumbling now tumultuously, and little waves
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: off from him the torpid sleep that had come upon him in the hot and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up from sleep. Soon we all eat, and then the helmsman laid him down
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: their choicest furs.

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down dancing from the fields of snow.

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smooth before us, into which we were carried by the leaps of Yann.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: plains stands fair Belzoond.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: light of the day.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreariness of the marches.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: over the plains of Tlun, and we saw the lights of Cappadarnia.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: along the banks of the Yann heard all that night in the helmsman's
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unknown tongue the little songs of cities that they knew not.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I awoke before dawn with a feeling that I was unhappy before I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: remembered why. Then I recalled that by the evening of the approaching
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: day, according to all foreseen probabilities, we should come to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Bar-Wul-Yann, and I should part from the captain and his sailors. And
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I had liked the man because he had given me of his yellow wine that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was set apart among his sacred things, and many a story he had told me
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: about his fair Belzoond between the Acroctian hills and the Hian Min.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I had liked the ways that his sailors had, and the prayers that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they prayed at evening side by side, grudging not one another their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alien gods. And I had a liking too for the tender way in which they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: often spoke of Durl and Duz, for it is good that men should love their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: native cities and the little hills that hold those cities up.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I had come to know who would meet them when they returned to their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: homes, and where they thought the meetings would take place, some in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a valley of the Acroctian hills where the road comes up from Yann,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: others in the gateway of one or another of the three cities, and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: others by the fireside in the home. And I thought of the danger that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had menaced us all alike outside Perdondaris, a danger that, as things
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have happened, was very real.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night, and how he had held our lives in his careful hands. And as I
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thought of this the helmsman ceased to sing, and I looked up and saw
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a pale light had appeared in the sky, and the lonely night had passed;
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the dawn widened, and the sailors awoke.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: favourable, we still held onwards.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Golnuz, and heard the pilgrims praying.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When we awoke after the midday rest we were coming near to Nen, the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all things, and watched the city from beyond the jungle.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Here we anchored, and the captain and I went up into the city and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found that the Wanderers had come into Nen.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Wanderers were a weird, dark tribe, that once in every seven
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years came down from the peaks of Mloon, having crossed by a pass that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is known to them from some fantastic land that lies beyond. And the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people of Nen were all outside their houses, and all stood wondering
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at their own streets. For the men and women of the Wanderers had
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crowded all the ways, and every one was doing some strange thing. Some
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that strange far desert from which the Wanderers came.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: barbed at the tips. And they sang, in the language of none, songs that
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that haunts dark places.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and as the tale wound on the whites of their eyes showed vividly in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: midst of them and smote none.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: could do nothing of that kind at all.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: greet the night, that is answered by the wolves on the heights of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the Lands of Dream. Then we clasped hands, uncouthly on his part,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for it is not the method of greeting in his country, and he commended
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my soul to the care of his own gods, to his little lesser gods, the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: humble ones, to the gods that bless Belzoond.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany

text: A MIRACLE
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There is a road in Rome that runs through an ancient temple that once
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods had loved; it runs along the top of a great wall, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: floor of the temple lies far down beneath it, of marble, pink and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: white.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Upon the temple floor I counted to the number of thirteen hungry cats.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Sometimes,' they said among themselves, 'it was the gods that lived
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: here, sometimes it was men, and now it's cats. So let us enjoy the sun
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on the hot marble before another people comes.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: For it was at that hour of a warm afternoon when my fancy is able to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hear the silent voices.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the fearful leanness of all those thirteen cats moved me to go
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into a neighbouring fish shop, and there to buy a quantity of fishes.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then I returned and threw them all over the railing at the top of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great wall, and they fell for thirty feet, and hit the sacred marble
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with a smack.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now, in any other town but Rome, or in the minds of any other cats,
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sight of fishes falling out of heaven had surely excited wonder.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They rose slowly, and all stretched themselves; then they came
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leisurely towards the fishes. 'It is only a miracle,' they said in
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their hearts.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE CASTLE OF TIME
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Presently there was a stir in one of the houses, and a bat flew out
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the door into the daylight, and three mice came running out of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: doorway down the step, an old stone cracked in two and held together
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by moss; and there followed an old man bending on a stick with a white
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beard coming to the ground, wearing clothes that were glossed with
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: use, and presently there came others out of the other houses, all of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them as old, and all hobbling on sticks. These were the oldest people
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that the King had ever beheld, and he asked them the name of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: village and who they were; and one of them answered: 'This is the City
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the Aged in the Territory of Time.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King said; 'Is Time then here?'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And one of the old men pointed to a great castle standing on a steep
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hill and said: 'Therein dwells Time, and we are his people;' and
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they all looked curiously at King Karnith Zo, and the eldest of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: villagers spoke again and said: 'Whence do you come, you that are so
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: young?' and Karnith Zo told him how he had come to conquer Time, to
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: save the world and the gods, and asked them whence they came.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the villagers said:
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'We are older than always, and know not whence we came, but we are the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people of Time, and here from the Edge of Everything he sends out his
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hours to assail the world, and you may never conquer Time.' But the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King went back to his armies, and pointed toward the castle on the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hill and told them that at last they had found the Enemy of the Earth;
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and they that were older than always went back slowly into their
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: houses with the creaking of olden doors. And they went across the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fields and passed the village. From one of his towers Time eyed them
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the while, and in battle order they closed in on the steep hill as
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time sat still in his great tower and watched.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But as the feet of the foremost touched the edge of the hill Time
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hurled five years against them, and the years passed over their heads
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the army still came on, an army of older men. But the slope seemed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: steeper to the King and to every man in his army, and they breathed
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more heavily. And Time summoned up more years, and one by one he
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hurled them at Karnith Zo and at all his men. And the knees of the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: army stiffened, and their beards grew and turned grey, and the hours
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and days and the months went singing over their heads, and their hair
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: turned whiter and whiter, and the conquering hours bore down, and the
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years rushed on and swept the youth of that army clear away till they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came face to face under the walls of the castle of Time with a mass of
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: howling years, and found the top of the slope too steep for aged men.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Slowly and painfully, harassed with agues and chills, the King rallied
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his aged army that tottered down the slope. Slowly the King led back
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his warriors over whose heads had shrieked the triumphant years. Year
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in, year out, they straggled southwards, always towards Zoon; they
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came, with rust upon their spears and long beards flowing, again into
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Astarma, and none knew them there.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: HERE ENDS 'SELECTIONS FROM THE WRITINGS OF LORD DUNSANY.'
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: FINISHED ON LADY DAY, IN THE YEAR NINETEEN HUNDRED AND TWELVE.
title: Selections from the Writings of Lord Dunsany
author: Dunsany, Lord
